urn:contentItem:5XWF-VDT1-JB0G-F2M1-00000-00'Techlash' puts top digital companies under pressure from all sides2020-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:08ZLexisNexis'Techlash' puts top digital companies under pressure from all sidesAndrej Sokolow in BerlinBerlin (dpa) -

Are the sunny days coming to an end for major US technology firms? After surviving multiple scandals, some wonder whether the sailing is going to get even tougher for Facebook, Twitter and other companies as the US political year heats up.

Are the sunny days coming to an end for major US technology firms? After surviving multiple scandals, some wonder whether the sailing is going to get even tougher for Facebook, Twitter and other companies as the US political year heats up.

For the longest time, US technology giants like Google and Facebook could count on loose regulations and generally favourable reactions, at least from politicians in their domestic market. They tended to be seen as dynamic, flagship companies that secured America's place in the world of tomorrow.

Those times are gone.

In 2019, "techlash" struck the large Silicon Valley platform technology companies with full force, reshaping their relationship with US authorities. When Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg is called before committees of the US Congress these days, he's often met with open hostility.

Google, Facebook and Amazon are subjects of an antitrust investigation by the US Justice Department. Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic Party candidate in the 2020 presidential election, advocates breaking up big tech companies to promote more competition. The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) slapped Facebook with a record 5-billion-dollar fine for privacy breaches in July.

When Amazon announced plans to build a 25,000-employee second headquarters in the Queens borough of New York City, opposition from residents, activists and local politicians was so fierce that it abandoned the project. English actor and comedian Sacha Baron Cohen, known in part for his movie "Borat," recently made waves by calling Facebook and other social media "the greatest propaganda machine in history."

How have things come to this?

A turning point was the US presidential election campaign in 2016, when Facebook and Twitter in particular were not only used by clever campaign strategists, but also to an unprecedented degree by propaganda teams from Russia. Nor was the public image of social media helped when Zuckerberg described the notion that fake news on Facebook may have influenced the election outcome as a "pretty crazy idea," an assessment he later walked back.

Then Facebook was pilloried in 2018 for the scandal involving the British political data firm Cambridge Analytica, hired by US President Donald Trump's 2016 election campaign. In 2014, the firm gained access to private information on tens of millions of American Facebook users, which was used to target voters with personalized political advertisements.

The uproar over the data breach, which had occurred years earlier and looked almost harmless compared with several other slip-ups by Facebook, was a sign of the times.

However, the mood of the US populace is darkening. According to a recent survey by the Pew Research Center, a Washington-based "fact tank," the share of Americans who see technology companies as having a positive impact on the United States has tumbled to 50 per cent from 71 per cent four years ago. What's more, negative views of the companies' impact on the country have nearly doubled during this period, from 17 to 33 per cent. 

US politicians have left no doubt that the country's big technology companies face tighter regulations. But with a presidential election less than a year away, political calculation may beplaying a part. An investigation by the Justice Department into whether major digital technology companies engage in anti-competitive practices comes amid claims by Trump that they suppress conservative views.

At the same time, Facebook has been criticized for its decision not to automatically take down provably false content from politicians - and thereby stay out of the political fray. 

That said, business continues to go splendidly for the technology giants. Facebook easily digested the FTC fine in just a quarter. And Google, hit with antitrust fines from the European Union now totalling more than 8 billion euros (about 9 billion US dollars), ploughs ahead unfazed. The companies' users also keep growing in numbers.

urn:contentItem:5XVV-43X1-JCBW-N1FR-00000-00'Techlash' that never was: how internet giants rode the wave2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:08ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 31'Techlash' that never was: how internet giants rode the waveMATTHEW FIELD

It was supposed to be the year of the "techlash" - a political, cultural and regulatory backlash against the world's biggest technology companies. Yet 2019's tidal wave did not quite break.

The movement has long been predicted: indeed, "techlash" was awarded digital word of the year by the American Dialect Society last January. It also made the shortlist of last year's Oxford English Dictionary (OED) words of the year.

Industry fears of a techlash were all the rage in late 2018 and well into 2019. From the fallout of the Cambridge Analytica scandal to shareholder revolts against Facebook, the phenomenon was perhaps most visible in the repeated grilling of technology chief executives before the US Congress and MPs in Parliament.

But the techlash faltered before it could truly take hold.

Facebook was slammed with fines, but they hardly made a dent on its income. The tech giant received a slap on the wrist from the UK's Information Commissioner's Office of £500,000, the maximum it could receive, for failures related to Cambridge Analytica. When it was slammed with a $5bn (£3.8bn) fine from the Federal Trade Commission, it barely blinked and its share price went up. In March, Google was hit with its third $1bn-plus fine by the European Commission.

Yet collectively, Big Tech has continued to soar this year. Facebook shares are up more than 50pc, Google nearly 30pc. Facebook has continued to pile on new users; it now has 2.5bn in total. The social networking giant is expected to post revenues of $70bn this year, up from around $56bn in 2018. Hardly signs of a crippling slowdown.

Following Facebook's fine and an order from the FTC last summer, former Facebook head of security Alex Stamos says: "This is a natural consequence of the shallow nature of the techlash." The real problem, he says, is a lack of meaningful competition against Facebook and a failure of US privacy laws.

While politicians have railed against technology firms, it can be argued that their grip over users' digital lives has only grown stronger. On average, Brits spend three hours and 15 minutes each day online. Despite concerns about "fake news", more people are getting their news from social networks. Across the pond, 52pc of US adults get their news from Facebook, according to research from Pew.

In the advertising sector, some data suggests that technology giants have actually consolidated their power since new data regulations such as GDPR came into effect. The smallest advertising technology companies lost market share after it was introduced, but Google only grew.

Thomas Philippon, a professor at NYU Stern and author of The Great Reversal, a book on competition, says: "In the US, we have seen a steady decline in enforcement in antitrust and regulations. Now there is a shift towards finally acknowledging there is a problem in digital markets."

He adds: "Everyone understands there is a problem, but maybe some are paying just lip service."

Europe has certainly been ahead of the curve in cracking down on technology giants. While some people accuse Brussels of unfairly targeting US firms, many of its reforms are being copied in the US at a state level.

"The one regulator that has taken a more active stance is the EU competition commission," says Florian Ederer, a professor at Yale. "But more radical people argue that its billiondollar fines are just a slap on the wrist." Philippon reckons there has been a change in attitude in the past year, particularly in the US, where heavy regulatory changes could be on the way. Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren has demanded rules to break up Apple, Google and Facebook if she is elected president next year.

Furthermore, investigations into the activities of Google, Facebook and Amazon are under way. The FTC is now thought to be considering an injunction against Facebook to stop its efforts to merge its Facebook, Messenger, WhatsApp and Instagram services - a move that critics claim is an attempt by the technology giant to stop it being broken up. Even the Republicans have turned their ire on Facebook and Google, accusing them of suppressing free speech by demonstrating bias against conservative voices.

"It's quite an achievement by Facebook that they are one of the only things policymakers in Washington agree on," says Philippon. "They are the only people in the US who can encourage a bipartisan agreement."

Could 2020 actually bring reforms that curb the power of GAFA [Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon]? The UK may be heading that way: the Competition and Markets Authority recently launched a consultation on proposals that could break up part of Google. In Whitehall, there are discussions surrounding a new Digital Markets Unit to be a technology regulator.

Theresa May's Government floated plans for a regulator that could perform a duty of care and tackle malicious content, while Boris Johnson's manifesto in the recent election proclaimed a desire to make the UK the safest place to be online.

Germany has taken matters further.

The Bundestag is currently preparing its digital competition laws - the Digitalisierungsgesetz - which would make control over data a key factor in determining if a company is behaving anti-competitively.

According to law firm Hogan Lovells, there are as many as 450 pieces of legislation or rules proposed in 2019 that could fall on Big Tech in 2020. But as the decade draws to a close, there are perhaps even more pressing challenges - and more radical solutions - that could emerge.

Calls to break up Big Tech will most likely be a key battleground of the 2020 US election. "What is weird about this market is it is critical to everyday life and national infrastructure, but it is all funded on an advertising model," says Professor Diane Coyle of the University of Cambridge. "That's not sustainable."

Even fiercer regulation, such as classing services such as Facebook as utilities, could emerge, she suggests.

Meanwhile, technology companies are not standing still. AI, autonomous machines, facial recognition and surveillance are playing an increasing role in their power and influence. Regulating these growing technologies and practices may require something far more seismic than this decade's so-called techlash.

<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/wsj/markets/2019/01/10/techlash-whipping-up-criticism-of-the-top-tech-companies/B3-CW054_WORDST_M_20190110100630.jpg"/><br/>A little over a year ago, when the Economist made predictions for "The World in 2018," one global theme that the magazine singled out was "the coming 'techlash.' " It described a reaction against Silicon Valley's tech giants such as Facebook, Google and Amazon, with growing calls for regulation and crackdowns on monopolistic policies.Looking back, the forecast was prescient. After a year when the big tech companies were rocked by scandals over data privacy concerns, reports of election manipulation and censorship practices, the Financial Times columnist Rana Foroohar declared "techlash" the word that best summed up 2018. It was named digital word of the year in voting last week by the American Dialect Society (over which I presided). The Economist has been issuing dire admonitions about a backlash against the tech elite ever since November 2013, when an editorial warned of a "coming tech-lash."

Oxford Dictionaries, which included "techlash" on its own shortlist for 2018 words of the year, identified that editorial as the first known use of the portmanteau term combining "technology" and "backlash." Oxford noted that it initially was hyphenated, "only later settling into its one-word state"-a typical evolution for this kind of lexical blend.The success of the blend relies on being able to identify the "-lash" syllable as a shortened form of "backlash," defined as a strong reaction by people against a trend or development. "Backlash" emerged in the early 19th century as a mechanical term for a jerking motion caused by loosely connected gears or other machine parts. "Lash," in turn, has meant "a sudden or violent blow" since the 14th century, especially the strike of a whip. "Lash" also got transferred to the flexible part of a whip that delivers the blow. Other "lash" words followed from these basic meanings. "Eyelashes," for instance, are so called because they resemble the lash of a whip. (In Old English, an eyelash was commonly known as a "bru," which also meant an eyebrow or eyelid.) The rise of the term "backlash" for an adverse social reaction in the 20th century gave rise to all sorts of new variants. The 1964 presidential campaign between Lyndon Johnson and Barry Goldwater was responsible for several such terms. Johnson faced a backlash from some white Democratic voters for the passage of the Civil Rights Act, which was confusingly called both a "blacklash" since it involved African-American civil rights, and a "whitelash" since whites were the ones reacting negatively. (As I wrote in a November 2016 column, "whitelash" reappeared in commentators' assessments of Donald Trump's electoral victory.)During the 1964 race, Johnson responded to poll numbers about the "backlash vote" by pointing to the possibility of a backlash against the backlash, which pollsters termed the "frontlash"-voters flipping to support the Democratic ticket because Goldwater's views were seen as too extreme. Johnson dissected the "backlash" and the "frontlash" on the campaign trail and even introduced a new variant, "smearlash," for the backlash against Goldwater's negative campaigning.In a "Peanuts" comic strip from October 1964, the cartoonist Charles Schulz spoofed these developments. Linus was running for student body president, and his sister Lucy presented him with poll numbers showing that he was winning "the backlash vote, the frontlash vote, the whiplash vote, the eyelash vote and the tongue lash vote." (Linus lost the election after giving an impassioned speech about the Great Pumpkin.)After the Johnson-Goldwater showdown, the creation of new "-lash" words died down, with occasional innovations cropping up like "Vietlash," coined in 1968 by the syndicated columnist Joseph Kraft to describe a backlash against those protesting the country's growing military involvement in Vietnam. Half a century later, the "techlash" has emerged as a potent new social reaction to reckon with, and technology leaders would be wise to fear its repercussions.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody -- thanks so much for joining us. Happy Friday.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, October 26th.

Your top stories right now just before 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Stocks are in selloff mode once again this morning. Take a look at futures indicating a sharp decline at the start of trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average down 250 points right now. That's 1 percent lower. The S&P 500 is down 1.25 percent. And the Nasdaq, even harder hit with a 165- point selloff expected at the open for the Nasdaq. That is two and a third lower right out of the gate.

Global markets also under selling pressure this morning. Take a look at European indices where you see the FT 100 down 1.5 percent, 100 points lower. The CAC 40 in Paris down two and a third percent, 121 points lower. And the DAX index in Germany down 2 percent, that's 220 points lower on the DAX.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board -- fractional moves in some cases. But the Hang Seng in Hong Kong was down better than 1 percent and the Kospi in Korea down 1.75 percent.

Technology earnings are in focus -- that is what's driving markets this morning. Take a look. Amazon shares are down 9.25 percent, weighing on the entire technology sector, as the company's revenue missed expectations last night.

For Intel, bucking the trend however, the stock is actually higher this morning by a fraction. It had better than expected results and also better than expected guidance from Intel.

Semiconductors got slammed this week as Texas Instruments led the whole group lower.

Investors are watching Google parent Alphabet as well. The company's profit was soaring but sales slowed down and that's what's impacting the stock. Sales revenue under pressure and the stock is down 6 percent right now on Alphabet.

Then a bombshell report over sexual misconduct at Alphabet, that's also weighing on the stock. We're going to tell you what happened there at Google in that regard.

Netflix is under fire this morning as well. The "Wall Street Journal" is out with a startling report about the streaming giant's corporate culture. The stock is down 4 percent on Netflix. Details coming up.

Then a view from the top -- Oracle CEO Mark Hurd and Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison weighing in on everything from growth to artificial intelligence and data security in my exclusive interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER, ORACLE: -- to fully automate discovery, and the second is discovery to get robots. Discovery to get robots (INAUDIBLE) because if they have robot attacks on our clouds and robot attacks on our data centers and our government agencies, you better have robotic defenses or cyber defenses that are Star Wars-ish.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This is the first time they've ever sat down for an interview together. We're going to bring that to you coming up.

All that coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Third Seven Advisors market strategist Michael Block is here, and Fox News contributor Liz Pete joining us as well. Great to see you this morning.

LIZ PETE, FOX NEWS CTR: Good morning. Nice to be here, I think. We have a lot to talk about, none of it good right now.

BARTIROMO: We've got a tough market this morning.

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Big morning. President Trump imposed tariffs on China and China wished us interesting times. We're seeing it in the markets.

BARTIROMO: Interesting times.

PETE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You've been bullish on this market pretty much. Has anything changed?

BLOCK: I've gotten bullish down here. I wasn't that bullish to start out with. I've always been growth over value. Right now, my premise is this. Longer term I think it's a great time to be buying stocks.

The analogy I keep using is markets are damaged. You can go out and break your leg, even if you're feeling good a particular morning, a week later you probably don't want to run outside and try to kick a field goal in the 30-degree weather. It takes time for things to heal.

We're in for some volatility and choppiness. But I think over time when you start buying these big tech stocks you're going to be happy in the long term.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to talk about this because we want to zero in on what's troubling the sector importantly this morning.

Joining the conversation, we've got the Energy Secretary here, Rick Perry joining us this morning; along with the chairwoman of the RNC, Ronna Romney McDaniel, just 12 days away from the midterm elections; Arizona Congressman Andy Biggs weighs in on the border crisis; and more of my exclusive interview with Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison and CEO Mark Hurd. Don't miss a moment of it.

Futures pointing to another big selloff this morning -- it has been obviously a volatile week even with yesterday's gain at the close.

Dow industrials this morning set to be down 218 points. Technology's leading the downward trend this morning because of disappointing earnings last night. The Nasdaq down 150 points, that's 2.5 percent lower on the Nasdaq.

And here's some of the damage in the premarket as you can see. Facebook down 3 percent, Amazon is down 9 percent right now, Apple's down 1.5 percent, Netflix down 4 percent, and Alphabet parent of Google down 5.67 percent.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is LJH Investment Advisors managing director, media and entertainment analyst Larry Haverty. Larry -- it's good to see you. Thanks very much for being here.

LARRY HAVERTY, MANAGING DIRECTOR, LJH INVESTMENT ADVISORS: Hi -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Has anything changed in terms of the backdrop for the large media technology companies that we're talking about today, like Google for example.

HAVERTY: I absolutely think it has -- Maria. You look at these stocks and they've been almost a religion. And I think some of the people are getting out of church.

Putting that in financial terms, if you look at -- and I think Amazon's the easiest place to start. If you look at their report on the surface, it looks terrific. They had a very, very strong revenue growth, stronger EBITD growth, the margin's improved, there's a lot of free cash flow.

But if you look below the surface, you can see the beginning of some warts developing. I think the thing that struck me was that the foreign growth was only 15 percent.

And you have a stock that's up in the neighborhood of $250 billion of sales and it sells at these multiples, you have to have foreign growth. And you look at India as a foreign market and is used to having more or less things for themselves and Wal-Mart is going to compete very vigorously in India. They just bought a local guy and they told their shareholders that they weren't going to make a whole lot of money there for the next couple years and the shareholders sent the stock up. So that's a warning sign to Amazon.

(CROSSTALK)

HAVERTY: The second warning sign, Maria -- I think you talked about it earlier and I'm concerned about it -- is I think there's going to be margin pressure from this shortage of employees. You go down to Florida and there are so many help wanted signs. I just don't think there are any legal workers available in most markets.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HAVERTY: And they've got to find 100,000 people at a time when the seasonal pressure of employers to add workers is very high.

(CROSSTALK)

HAVERTY: So I think it's going to have some inefficiencies in the fourth quarter.

BARTIROMO: There are a lot of things coming together to sort of create this uncertainty. Earlier this week we spoke with AlphaOne Capital Partners founding partner Dan Niles and he summed it up this way.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHAONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: This is the longest bull market in the S&P 500 since World War II. It's been up for 115 months. The gains over that period of time are up over 330 percent which is the second biggest gain during a bull market since World War II.

But if you look at the big picture around growth, you've got a lot of concerns. You've got China starting to slow down. Auto sales in China went from being up 15 percent year over year in April to down 10 in the most recent month. That's a pretty big change.

You've got concerns over Italy and Brexit in Europe. And in the U.S. interest rates are going up. They're at the highest levels in seven years.

What you've seen in general during this earnings season with Boeing being a pretty big exception, is that a lot of companies are guiding much lower.

I'll give you an example. Texas Instruments reported last night and I think they're one of the best indicators in terms of global health. They do about $16 billion in revenues, $100 billion in market cap.

They missed revenue expectations for the first time since the fourth quarter of 2015. So it's been almost three years since they missed the top line. They talked about every major end market slowing down and they weren't sure when it was going to stop.

BARTIROMO: Are we looking at fundamentals deteriorating within technology?

NILES: I think you absolutely are. And this is exacerbated by the fact that you have a lot of inventory out there. So if you pick the biggest company in the world -- Apple, for example. They have 89 percent inventory growth year over year in the June quarter that they reported. The revenues are up 17 percent.

Well, what if the iPhone doesn't sell well? They're going to have to barn that inventory off when we get into the March quarter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: There you go. And that's why we're seeing revenue under pressure -- Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Right. Dan Niles was mentioning the Texas Instruments revenue but Larry -- 43 percent of the S&P 500 companies that have reported so far have missed revenue expectations. That is a big number and certainly the biggest percentage that we've seen this year.

One viewer noted on Twitter, "Don't the earnings matter more than the revenue?" And I said well, you can get to earnings by cutting costs because your taxes are lower. Ultimately if you're a growth company, you better be growing that revenue and faster and faster every quarter.

HAVERTY: Well, if you didn't like the third quarter, you're for sure not going to like the fourth quarter because the dollar's strengthening. And in the fourth quarter sales are seasonally stronger so the mountain's higher.

So you're looking at a fourth quarter where just because of this labor thing, you're going to have employment shortages and margin pressure. You're going to have interest expense going up way more than it has in past years.

I think it's really been 30 years since we've had a good interest rate cycle and we've got a good interest rate cycle going, at least until the last couple weeks.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HAVERTY: And it doesn't look like you're going to get any help from China. China's being very difficult and I think the political situation there is scary. So there's plenty of room for causes personally since stocks aren't -- I think stocks are reasonable now. I don't think they're expensive. But they certainly aren't cheap.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PETE: I was going to say, I mean earnings are growing at 20 percent and after all, that does bring the multiples down. I'm not talking about tech necessarily but overall it seems to me valuations are pretty good.

HAVERTY: Well, I think right now you're at a point where most of the companies can't be buying the stock in the market because they're --

PETE: Right -- which is another big factor --

HAVERTY: -- in reporting mode.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

HAVERTY: The market is usually bottomed in October and another thing that doesn't get a lot of press is mutual fund tax loss selling. Most mutual fund companies try to minimize their tax liabilities by selling their losers.

So there's a lot of pressure seasonally on the market. And that pressure is going to erode. And I think people will be looking at the 10-year at 3.08 percent and saying "Oh my gosh, let's buy a couple stocks, I can get a 5 percent plus yield in the telephone company and Verizon." You know, what's so bad about that now that they have media exposure to make them grow a little faster.

PETE: Actually that's a good point.

(CROSSTALK)

HAVERTY: I think we're close to the bottom.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Michael -- you know, what Dan Niles said the other day, the average dividend yield within the S&P 500 is 1.8 percent. So can you get 3 percent in the two-year versus 1.8 percent in the stock market, that's -- there you go.

BLOCK: We'll see. There's a tradeoff there.

Larry -- one thing really quickly here, you know, we're talking about wage pressures and the effect that they have on margins. I heard this argument six months ago. Retailers were supposedly going to go down on this. Banks were out pitching hedge funds on baskets of stocks they should short because of wage pressure.

Well guess what, those retailers were able to pass on price increases. That was spelled out in the Beige Book in another evidence we got. And those retailer stocks continue to rally.

Do you think that scenario could be repeated here? Can retailers pass on price increases in the holiday season?

HAVERTY: I think the retail stocks rallied because they were trading at six to eight times EBITD versus 30 plus times for Amazon and close to 20 plus times for Google. So the stocks were very undervalued.

I think there's going to be margin pressure -- there can't not be. The world is just very, very competitive and rates are up and wage costs are going to be up and you can see this in the macroeconomic statistics.

So I think the seas are going to be rough but we're at a level where there's still a lot of free cash flow, the world certainly doesn't need more retail stores.

Google's really the only company that I can see that is really sharply accelerating their capital spending. And we'll see how that works later on. And I think a lot of that's related to Waymo which I think is going to be potentially a big proposition.

So, you know, I think it's going to get worse before it gets better. But I think we're very close to where it's going to get better and there are a lot of good things going on and I think the -- they're going to be recognized.

But first we've got to get through this seasonal pain and some stock- specific pain when margins go down.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HAVERTY: So much money is being managed now by machines and machines have been programmed not to like margin pressure.

BARTIROMO: Of course, yes.

HAVERTY: And you need to get out of the way of the machines when they're doing their thing.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Humans don't like margin pressure also. Machines and humans -- they don't like margin pressure.

Larry -- it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for your insights.

HAVERTY: Thanks -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Very much appreciated. Larry Haverty joining us there.

Coming up -- the search for a sender intensifies with authorities now zeroing in on Florida after locating a tenth suspicious package. The very latest details there.

Then President Trump tackling high drug prices -- we will tell you about the plan to lower the cost of your medications, right after this.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We're watching markets lower this morning. Take a look at what we're expecting at the start of trading. Dow Industrial down 220 points, almost 1 percent. S&P 500 is down better than 1 percent. And the Nasdaq with a decline of better than 2 percent, 148 points lower.

This happens to be off of the lows of the morning I should point out. But this has everything to do with earnings last night within the tech sector and revenue misses specifically.

Meanwhile there is an intense nationwide manhunt underway after 10 suspicious packages were sent to prominent Democrats this week.

Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well Maria -- federal investigators are now increasingly focusing on south Florida. They searched a mail facility in the region, that was last night. Several pipe bomb packages went through that facility.

Former vice president Joe Biden was one of those targets.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: These pipe bombs being mailed might wake everybody in my business up a little bit and realize that we have to begin to put this country back together again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Meanwhile President Trump tweeting, "Funny how lowly-rated CNN and others can criticize me at will, even blaming me for the current spate of bombs and ridiculously comparing this to September 11th and the Oklahoma City bombing. Yet when I criticize them they go wild and scream it's just not presidential."

Well, speaking of President Trump, he is taking action to address the rising cost of health care. Trump unveiling a test plan to lower Medicare drug prices by matching them to their prices in other countries. If approved this could ultimately save taxpayers billions but the proposal expected to face opposition from drug makers.

And just in time for Halloween, Starbucks has a new brew. It's called the Witch's Brew frappuccino. Even though it is mostly purple, it's pretty much an orange creamsicle. Not to give this away, I'm sorry. But that's basically what this is.

It's got orange cream flavoring, green swirl, but there's chia seeds on top and then it's got vanilla whipped cream on it and then matcha powder which is green. They posted it to Facebook with the poem that says "Wart of bat, breath of toad, howl of cat, yum bestowed". There you go -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Weird. That's weird.

CASONE: The stock is lower -- Starbucks is lower in the premarket.

Yes, we have them on set. And so these are -- and, you know, it's limited time. This goes -- remember, we had the Franken Frappuccino. And last year, Maria -- we brought you the Zombie Frappuccino. Now we're getting the Witch's Brew Frappucino.

MCDOWELL: What color was the zombie? Do you remember? Was it the same color?

CASONE: No it wasn't purple as this one. The Zombie was more green. It's funny because this is like -- they should put this in a new cup. I'm like yes, it's only good for about a week and then it's over.

PETE: Wow, with orange or -- I don't know.

CASONE: Yes. But they also come -- they're going to serve mummy cake pops and they're going to serve raccoon sugar cookies.

BARTIROMO: Do these just work? Do these gimmicks work?

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do they get people in?

CASONE: The Zombie Frappucino last year they ran out of ingredients for the Zombie Frappuccino because they were so popular.

BARTIROMO: -- which were zombies, of course.

CASONE: I know.

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: This is really goo.

CASONE: Well, we don't talk calories on the show.

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: It's gluten free. It's keto-friendly. Don't worry about it.

CASONE: Yes, right.

BARTIROMO: None of the above.

CASONE: Diet November 1st, people, come on.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much -- Cheryl.

All right. Coming up, markets are under pressure this morning -- disappointing results from Amazon and Google. Those stocks lower and that is dragging on the Nasdaq, that's for sure. The Dow Industrials down 200 points. The Nasdaq down 141. We've got more on that coming up.

Then oil prices headed for a third weekly decline as well. The Energy Secretary Rick Perry is joining us exclusively next to talk about the state of the U.S. energy sector.

Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are watching oil and the energy sector. Oil prices falling as oversupply becomes a concern. As you could see, crude oil now at $66.47.

Reuters is reporting that the Saudi OPEC governor says a potential oil glut could become an issue in the fourth quarter.

Joining me right now is the Energy Secretary Rick Perry. Secretary -- it's good to see you.

RICK PERRY, U.S. ENERGY SECRETARY: It's good to be here -- Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So your reaction to that? Are we looking at a glut now?

PERRY: It's a snapshot in time and we know that stable supply is really the most important issue to us so we don't get these spikes and ups and downs. So right now, there's a bit more than what the market is using but that can vanish in a hurry.

BARTIROMO: We've been talking so much about the U.S. becoming a bigger and bigger producer. So with all of the headlines around Saudi Arabia right now, with Jamal Khashoggi news -- does the U.S. need Saudi Arabia oil?

PERRY: Well, the world market does. And, you know, this is a global market. The United States is now the number one oil and gas producing country in the world.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

PERRY: By 2020 we will be a net oil exporter. I mean it's just fascinating what's happened in a decade. It shows what innovation and technology can do.

With all of that said, the world market is going to need this energy -- all kinds of energy. When you think about the European market, the American LNG that's going in there now, the geopolitics of that, where no longer does Poland or Romania have to -- or Germany for that matter be relying upon Russian gas singularly.

So the world is really reliant now on American energy but we're also obviously relying upon other countries. You've got problems in Venezuela. You've got problems in Angola. The sanctions on Iran are out there.

So the market is -- it's critical that we keep the supply up and that's the reason that infrastructure is so important in the United States oilfields.

The limiting factor in the Permian Basin, which is the third largest oilfield in the world --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

PERRY: -- is pipeline capacity.

BARTIROMO: So what about that? What do we need to do in terms of infrastructure to build up this pipeline, that one and others?

PERRY: The President is really focused on this. He understands that you've got to get this to market and pipelines are one of the key issues there. And when you talk about infrastructure, it's not just pipelines.

When you think about midland Odessa out in West Texas, it's about hospitals and schools and roads and being able to have places for people to live literally. That's all part of this infrastructure because this is a generational change that's occurring in America and in turn affecting the world.

So the President has basically said we're going to go try to build this infrastructure as fast as we can. That means FERC has got to be moving and moving quickly. That means that agencies that have regulatory control over all of these different things, it may be the Corps of Engineers, it may be the DOE.

All of those need to be on point, that as we build this infrastructure you need your regulatory climate to be one that is very nimble and very expeditious.

BARTIROMO: Understood.

Before I get to your event-- the Iran sanctions, going into effect next week or --

PERRY: Correct, in November.

BARTIROMO: Next week -- in November. What's the impact on the oil market?

PERRY: Well obviously, we don't know completely. I suggest that the market's already been impacted by it, people knew they were coming in, those contracts were already been forwarded by then.

BARTIROMO: Anticipated.

PERRY: Anticipated -- yes, ma'am. So I don't think there will be much in the market standpoint. Hopefully it will send the appropriate message to Iran. Listen, be a decent neighbor in the neighborhood and you don't have to face these kind of things.

BARTIROMO: We'll see about that.

Your event, you'll be touring the Brookhaven Lab on Long Island today. Tell us about that. Why is this facility important? Why are you going there?

PERRY: Well we have 17 national labs. And these are the most fascinating -- it's what makes my job as cool as it is -- Maria. These national labs, all across the country, you know, the Manhattan Project out at Los Alamos, through Sandia through Pacific Northwest Lab -- I mean fascinating work they produce.

Brookhaven -- things that you don't necessarily connect with Department of Energy. early work was done on Parkinson's disease at the Brookhaven Lab.

BARTIROMO: So these are medical labs?

PERRY: No, they're energy labs but we do a host of different things across the -- I mean all of the nuclear weapons work is done at our national labs. But they also -- we delve into things like into water. I mean these are where a lot of ideas get thrown out and tested in the federal government to see, you know, what is the next big thing.

Something -- the first video game was developed at Brookhaven Lab out on the end of Long Island. So this is my 17th lab to go to.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic.

PERRY: This gets me --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Well this really -- this shows us the innovation of America, right, what's really going on.

PERRY: And that's what national labs are really about, you know. You've got Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, DARPA over at DOD. They do like types of work but the national labs -- if there are a set of crown jewels in America, I would suggest to you our national labs are them.

The men and women who work there are brilliant. They're fascinating men and women who across the board -- we're working on issues of traumatic brain injury and post traumatic stress at our national labs as well.

BARTIROMO: I know that.

PERRY: It's fascinating work that's going on.

BARTIROMO: And of course, we don't he know enough about the brain -- Alzheimer's and autism.

PERRY: Correct. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So this is really important work.

Real quick before you go, obviously coming from Texas, your thoughts on this migrant caravan? I mean President Trump is maintaining this hard stance with reports that indicate he is prepared to sign an executive order, barring those illegal immigrants from entering the United States.

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen reiterated that last night. What do you see?

PERRY: Yes. I'll give you an interesting -- we've had these challenges while I was the governor in the state of Texas. I asked for -- I requested 800 federal troops to come to assist us along the border back with the previous administration.

We finally have a president, who is willing to protect, defend the border of the United States. And as a Texan, as a former governor, I say thank God.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Especially since you have a whole long line of people that are doing it legally, that are waiting on line to get in legally.

PERRY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You've got this people trying to get to the front of the line. So --

PERRY: You've never had anybody send a message of listen, this border is going to be sacrosanct. If you want to come in the United States, you come in legally -- you come in legally.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PERRY: And Donald Trump, the first president who's been able to stand up and say, we're going to stop it.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, it's good to see you this morning.

PERRY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Secretary Rick Perry joining us.

Coming up, markets are under pressure once again this morning, disappointing results from Amazon and Google setting the tone for markets. We've got more on that coming up after this.

And then my exclusive sit-down interview with Larry Ellison and Mark Hurd. The two weigh in on Oracle's R&D spending, cyber security and a lot more. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: S&P 500 is down by better than one percent and the NASDAQ with a 137 point selloff right now, good for a two percent selloff right at the opening of trading this morning.

We had weak results in the technology sector, that's putting pressure on markets this morning because revenue was light. Look at Amazon, down nine percent. Look at Alphabet, parent of Google, up -- down five percent. Investors are watching out for that.

And Amazon, after the technology giants released disappointing sales numbers last night. And it is digging through the tech sector this morning. Techs instruments of course, was down big this week as well. Semi-conductors rolling over.

In Europe this morning, markets are lower across the board with the FT-100 down one percent, the CAC Quarante down two percent and the DAX Index down 1-1/2 percent.

Overnight in Asia, markets were down across the board.

It is the busiest week of earnings season so far coming to a close this morning. Some big names still reporting earnings, Colgate Palmolive is down better than one -- it is down in the premarket rather, after less than Stellar earnings as well. We were just watching the price of oil which is down about one percent.

Oracle executive chairman Larry Ellison and CEO Mark Hurd sitting down for their first joined interview ever in a Fox Business exclusive. The leaders weighed in on their competition and why Oracle Cloud technology they say is the best in the business. CEO Mark Hurd revealing a huge bump in R&D spending.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK HURD, CEO, ORACLE: It was six, seven years ago, we spent $3.7 billion in R&D. We'll spend over $6 billion in R&D this year, so you get a context of how much we've invested into these new cool products, all the stuff we've got that's now available in the Cloud.

The customers expect, they've got a lot of issues, I mean, they spent 25 years building up these extremely heterogeneous architectures. Almost like a Lego set as we talked a bit yesterday, very complicated. Hard for a customer to even know what they have in their inventory of applications and tools and middleware, etcetera.

So, this is a very hard environment to modernize, to upgrade, to secure, to Larry's point. And so, what you you can't -- one thing with our customers is that they probably on average have hundreds of configurations. And our Cloud, we have one, one configuration.

Well, it's scaled. Much easier for us to upgrade, modernize and to secure.

BARTIROMO: I understand. I mean, and the reason I said unlimited spend, I was speaking to some financial services executives the other day. Jamie Dimon told me that they will spend almost $1 billion on securing their data, on cyber in the next year. Which is -- that's what I'm saying. These companies cannot afford to have any slip-ups.

LARRY ELLISON, EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: Well, --

BARTIROMO: To have any vulnerabilities.

ELLISON: Yes, and first of all, I love Jamie Dimon. I think he's the world's preeminent banker (INAUDIBLE). I probably made some enemies by saying that. He's an incredible guy, incredible executive.

But if Google can't protect their network, if Facebook can't protect their network, it's challenging for J.P. Morgan -- you know Chase to protect their network.

This is not -- this is not a trivial exercise. They can spend $1 billion. We spend more than $1 billion securing our network. So does Facebook. So does Google. It's a hard problem.

BARTIROMO: Who are the bad actors? What do they want? Do they want to just -- what, they want anything, steal money? What do they want? And who are the bad actors?

ELLISON: There are two -- there are two classes. There are people who want to steal a lot of credit cards and just make money. And then there are state actors who want to gain intelligence.

The -- a government agency that -- basically the Ministry for Personnel in the United States was hacked by a government actor who was able to get all of the resumes for everyone in the White House, all of the -- all of the -- Office of Personnel Management it's called. And the state actor took all of that information with all the --

BARTIROMO: I remember that (INAUDIBLE)

ELLISON: Yes, all the government agencies and took it all and they were able to analyze it. And they -- for example, they did something very clever. They said these are the people who work for the government. These are all the people that work at this embassy and our capital city. How come there are some people that work on the -- in the embassy, in the capital city that aren't in the list of government employees? Maybe they all work for CIA.

We -- they were able to find out a lot of things about our intelligence agencies by hacking into the office of Personnel Management and just comparing data.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

ELLISON: So, it was an extraordinary setback for us and we have to do a much better job of securing -- of securing data.

There are plenty of -- you know, financial services firms, you read about that don't secure their databases and you end up -- they end up above the fold on the New York Times report and the CEO gets fired because they don't patch their databases in a timely fashion.

The only way you can handle that -- the only way you can handle that, is to fully automate the database patching. You have to fully automate threat discovery and the second is discover, your robots. Discover your robots have to patch it. Because if they have robot attacks on our Clouds and robot attacks on our data centers and our government agencies, you better have a robotic defenses or so, you know, cyber defenses that are Star Wars- ish.

BARTIROMO: Wow, this is a moment in time where there's -- aren't many things more important than this.

HURD: Well, this is at the CEO level now, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HURD: So, I mean, this is not a conversation that people like just Larry and I have. I mean, this is a conversation that --

BARTIROMO: Right.

HURD: -- is at the CEO level. The example that Larry just brought up, there's a customer that actually bought encryption to their database.

ELLISON: Yes.

HURD: And actually didn't implement it.

So, to my knowledge, no customer -- nobody has ever de-encrypted an encrypted Oracle database. Less, you talked about unlimited spending. Less than one percent and I'm sure I'm roughly right, of our databases are encrypted. Of the people that bought our encryption, half of actually not implemented it.

So, that -- and that's just one of the things we can do. By the way, in our Cloud, all of the customers' data is encrypted.

ELLISON: Yes, there's no option. Right now -- historically, the customers were they've given a choice, encryption, optional. You can turn it on. Some people thinks -- you know, think encryption slows performance a little bit. In our Cloud, we have no options, everything is encrypted. It's encrypted at rest, it's encrypted in transit.

Inside of different customers, as I say, the big -- the hardest thing is to know what you even have. This one big customer who -- you know, had to go to the CEO, found that they had patched some that they had a database called Apache Struts. And they -- there was a big security vulnerability. And they patched about 80 percent of their Apache Struts databases. They couldn't even find all their databases.

Unfortunately, the ones they didn't patch lost millions and millions of you know, consumer financial records.

BARTIROMO: You've got a lot of competitors at your -- at your heels. We know that. So, let me ask you about that, Mark, because these markets are nervous, another 600 point selloff today because people are worried about growth. Does this even become part of the conversation? You cannot -- you know, give up or give in on this kind of spend in terms of securing your data.

HURD: First of all, in points to Larry's bringing it up, we're the only one that has this capability. So, when you look at the market depending on which competitors you're talking about. You know, we invest in technology. I think the core of Oracle -- I mean, we have our founder's DNA in the entire company which is to continue to innovate.

And for us, when you talk about these things we just talked through, patching, whether it's encryption, all of these now are inherent. The separation and segregation of data on the control plan from where the customer's data is, these are all fundamentals of what we're bringing to market.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HURD: And frankly we're highly differentiated in this area.

BARTIROMO: Have you seen any change in terms of the global outlook that would warrant this kind of nervousness in terms of growth?

HURD: I told you what I thought yesterday. I mean, I think the U.S. economy is going fine. And when we look particularly at mid-market and I gave you the example of some of our --

BARTIROMO: Net suite.

HURD: -- our net suite business.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HURD: Which has had an unbelievable run.

Now, some of that is caused by things we've done, frankly, to add more salespeople, to add more engineers. But at the same time, our net suite business grew over 70 percent in our fiscal Q4, grew over 40 percent in our fiscal Q1 in bookings.

I think that's indicative (INAUDIBLE). Most of that growth was in the United States. And that's indicative of where we think the mid-market is in the U.S. it's growing. It's investing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Futures are under pressure this morning, markets are selling off once again, disappointing results last night from Amazon and Google parent Alphabet. We've got more on those numbers and the outlooks coming up.

And then, a sweet surprise, one kindergarten class bringing their deaf custodian to tears by signing happy birthday. The amazing video, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are troubled this morning. Take a look, we're expecting a decline at the start of trading, the Dow Jones Industrial average down 227 points, that's about one percent lower right now on the Dow. S&P is down better than one percent and the NASDAQ with a decline of 147 points, that's better than two percent. NASDAQ getting hit as technology rolls over this morning on the heels of revenue misses within tech.

Meanwhile, there's this, Russian President Vladimir Putin may soon be headed to Washington. Cheryl Casone with the details there in headlines, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Just getting this news this morning, Maria. National security advisor John Bolton is now saying the White House has extended an invite to Putin but no word on whether he's accepted. President Trump and Putin have only held one bilateral summit that was in Helsinki, Finland, that was back in July. Trump was criticized after the summit, accused of failing to stand up to Putin regarding election meddling. Russia continues to deny that they interfered in the 2016 election.

The two leaders will meet in November on the sidelines of events in Paris commemorating the end of World War I.

Well, Tobacco giant Altria trying to combat teen vaping. The maker of, yes, Marlboro cigarettes, has announced it's pulling its e-cig pods from their store shelves. They're also removing exotic flavors from the market. This comes after the drug -- Food and Drug Administration -- excuse me, called underage use of e-vaping products an epidemic. Those flavors of course, very popular with kids. Altria stock is down 12 percent so far this year.

And then finally there is this, on a different note, a kindergarten class in Tennessee gave a very special gift to a school teacher.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Happy birthday to you. Happy birthday dear James.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: (INAUDIBLE) He works at the school. The Hickerson Elementary Kindergarten class surprised their friend. He's the custodian there known as Mr. James, he is deaf and the kids had only sang happy birthday but as you can see, they signed it as well. And I don't know, Maria, I think he's holding back tears in this video. It's kind of hard to see. But it was great.

BARTIROMO: That is beautiful.

MCDOWELL: Well, I'm crying.

CASONE: (INAUDIBLE) they just want a surprise for him you know, and how sweet that all those kids learned it. That's tough. Sign language is hard, right, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Yes, I taught myself sign language, a lot of it. I still know the Alphabet, the ASL Alphabet. I taught myself out of the encyclopedia Britannic when I was five.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That was so sweet. Thank you so much, Cheryl.

All right, we want to get into the GDP when we come back.

And then there's this, a search for the sender intensifies, authorities now zeroing in on Florida after locating a tenth suspicious package sent to a prominent Democrat. RNC Chairwoman Ronna Romney McDaniel is here to weigh in. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Dualing rallies, President Trump is headed to North Carolina this evening, his predecessor, President Obama is in Wisconsin around the same time, this with what, 11 days to go before the midterm elections now. I want to bring in RNC chairman, Ronna Romney McDaniel. Ronna, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us.

RONNA ROMNEY MCDANIEL, CHAIRWOMAN, RNC: Thanks for having me. Always good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, how are you feeling 11 days out? Tell us -- set the stage for us for these midterm elections. What's most important and what has changed?

MCDANIEL: Well, the most important thing obviously, is turning out your vote, making sure that your base has energy to go out and actually vote. And that's why the president is so instrumental as he's traveling from state to state and having these huge epic rallies like the one he had in Texas the other day, like the one he's going to have in North Carolina. He reminds voters not only go vote, talk to your family, sign up at Vote.GOP. We need to get these candidates over the finish line so I can keep this majority and keep this comeback going for the American people.

BARTIROMO: Now, the money has been an issue, right? The last time we spoke, we talked about a couple of very deep pocketed Democrats who were putting a lot of money into the Dimms and these Congressional races, like Michael Bloomberg giving $80 million to the Democrats. Tom Steyer in California $120 million. How are the Republicans doing on the money end of thing?

MCDANIEL: Yes, well, the progressive Democrat billionaires are trying to buy this election. And so, we know what this congressional members would do if they come to Washington. They'll be withhold unto the special interest. But the RNC has raised record money. We just passed $269 million raised. We're putting it into the ground game in all these states. We've been building it for two years.

So, we've made 60 million voter contacts, that's more than we did in 2016. And that's going to help really propel and drive out our vote as we're knocking doors, making calls, using digital and mail to talk to voters and we have something to say.

We've done things in Washington, four million new jobs, 4.2 percent GDP. Our country is on the rise. What are Democrats going to say? We've obstructed and resisted at every turn? They have nothing to run on except stopping this comeback that the American people are feeling in their pocketbooks.

BARTIROMO: And you've denounced this hate and these packages, the hunt is on this morning for whoever sent at least 10 suspicious packages to the presidents' most vocal critics.

The Feds turning their attention to Florida and New York this morning. Very early this morning President Trump tweeted this. Funny how lowly rated CNN and others can criticize me at will even blaming me for the current spate of bombs and ridiculously comparing this to September 11th and the Oklahoma City bombing. Yet, when I criticize them they go wild and scream it's just not presidential. Your reaction?

MCDANIEL: Well, I think the president has led the way on this when he has said this is a time to unify. He has condemned obviously these heinous acts by these cowardly individuals. And the Democrats did the exact opposite. They play the blame game. They continue to divide. You saw the head of CNN make a ridiculous statement, blaming this on the president and Sarah Sanders.

Once again, the Democrats cannot unify with this president and that is why we need more Republicans in Washington. We need to reject the Democrat playbook of resist, obstruct, divide, and the only way they rewrite the way they do business in Washington is if they lose and then we will get unity in Washington.

BARTIROMO: You know, there was Philippe Reines on Tucker the other night. He works -- obviously, he used to work with Hillary Clinton. And he basically said look, I'm very comfortable with Sarah Sanders getting kicked out of a restaurant, very comfortable with Kirstjen Nielsen getting kicked out of restaurants because they lie. So, I mean, it's almost like they continue to have this dog whistles.

MCDANIEL: Yes, it's shameful. It's not good for our country. And the president has stepped up and led.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Ronna, it's good to see you. Thanks very much.

MCDANIEL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ronna Romney McDaniel.

Still ahead, markets are under pressure. We've got a lot more ahead of the GDP report out in 30 minutes, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody -- thanks so much for joining us. Happy Friday.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, October 26th.

Your top stories right now just before 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Stocks are in selloff mode once again this morning. Take a look at futures indicating a sharp decline at the start of trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average down 250 points right now. That's 1 percent lower. The S&P 500 is down 1.25 percent. And the Nasdaq, even harder hit with a 165- point selloff expected at the open for the Nasdaq. That is two and a third lower right out of the gate.

Global markets also under selling pressure this morning. Take a look at European indices where you see the FT 100 down 1.5 percent, 100 points lower. The CAC 40 in Paris down two and a third percent, 121 points lower. And the DAX index in Germany down 2 percent, that's 220 points lower on the DAX.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board -- fractional moves in some cases. But the Hang Seng in Hong Kong was down better than 1 percent and the Kospi in Korea down 1.75 percent.

Technology earnings are in focus -- that is what's driving markets this morning. Take a look. Amazon shares are down 9.25 percent, weighing on the entire technology sector, as the company's revenue missed expectations last night.

For Intel, bucking the trend however, the stock is actually higher this morning by a fraction. It had better than expected results and also better than expected guidance from Intel.

Semiconductors got slammed this week as Texas Instruments led the whole group lower.

Investors are watching Google parent Alphabet as well. The company's profit was soaring but sales slowed down and that's what's impacting the stock. Sales revenue under pressure and the stock is down 6 percent right now on Alphabet.

Then a bombshell report over sexual misconduct at Alphabet, that's also weighing on the stock. We're going to tell you what happened there at Google in that regard.

Netflix is under fire this morning as well. The "Wall Street Journal" is out with a startling report about the streaming giant's corporate culture. The stock is down 4 percent on Netflix. Details coming up.

Then a view from the top -- Oracle CEO Mark Hurd and Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison weighing in on everything from growth to artificial intelligence and data security in my exclusive interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER, ORACLE: -- to fully automate discovery, and the second is discovery to get robots. Discovery to get robots (INAUDIBLE) because if they have robot attacks on our clouds and robot attacks on our data centers and our government agencies, you better have robotic defenses or cyber defenses that are Star Wars-ish.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This is the first time they've ever sat down for an interview together. We're going to bring that to you coming up.

All that coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Third Seven Advisors market strategist Michael Block is here, and Fox News contributor Liz Pete joining us as well. Great to see you this morning.

LIZ PETE, FOX NEWS CTR: Good morning. Nice to be here, I think. We have a lot to talk about, none of it good right now.

BARTIROMO: We've got a tough market this morning.

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Big morning. President Trump imposed tariffs on China and China wished us interesting times. We're seeing it in the markets.

BARTIROMO: Interesting times.

PETE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HURD: Which has had an unbelievable run.

Now, some of that is caused by things we've done, frankly, to add more salespeople, to add more engineers. But at the same time, our net suite business grew over 70 percent in our fiscal Q4, grew over 40 percent in our fiscal Q1 in bookings.

I think that's indicative (INAUDIBLE). Most of that growth was in the United States. And that's indicative of where we think the mid-market is in the U.S. it's growing. It's investing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Futures are under pressure this morning, markets are selling off once again, disappointing results last night from Amazon and Google parent Alphabet. We've got more on those numbers and the outlooks coming up.

And then, a sweet surprise, one kindergarten class bringing their deaf custodian to tears by signing happy birthday. The amazing video, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are troubled this morning. Take a look, we're expecting a decline at the start of trading, the Dow Jones Industrial average down 227 points, that's about one percent lower right now on the Dow. S&P is down better than one percent and the NASDAQ with a decline of 147 points, that's better than two percent. NASDAQ getting hit as technology rolls over this morning on the heels of revenue misses within tech.

Meanwhile, there's this, Russian President Vladimir Putin may soon be headed to Washington. Cheryl Casone with the details there in headlines, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Just getting this news this morning, Maria. National security advisor John Bolton is now saying the White House has extended an invite to Putin but no word on whether he's accepted. President Trump and Putin have only held one bilateral summit that was in Helsinki, Finland, that was back in July. Trump was criticized after the summit, accused of failing to stand up to Putin regarding election meddling. Russia continues to deny that they interfered in the 2016 election.

The two leaders will meet in November on the sidelines of events in Paris commemorating the end of World War I.

Well, Tobacco giant Altria trying to combat teen vaping. The maker of, yes, Marlboro cigarettes, has announced it's pulling its e-cig pods from their store shelves. They're also removing exotic flavors from the market. This comes after the drug -- Food and Drug Administration -- excuse me, called underage use of e-vaping products an epidemic. Those flavors of course, very popular with kids. Altria stock is down 12 percent so far this year.

And then finally there is this, on a different note, a kindergarten class in Tennessee gave a very special gift to a school teacher.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Happy birthday to you. Happy birthday dear James.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: (INAUDIBLE) He works at the school. The Hickerson Elementary Kindergarten class surprised their friend. He's the custodian there known as Mr. James, he is deaf and the kids had only sang happy birthday but as you can see, they signed it as well. And I don't know, Maria, I think he's holding back tears in this video. It's kind of hard to see. But it was great.

BARTIROMO: That is beautiful.

MCDOWELL: Well, I'm crying.

CASONE: (INAUDIBLE) they just want a surprise for him you know, and how sweet that all those kids learned it. That's tough. Sign language is hard, right, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Yes, I taught myself sign language, a lot of it. I still know the Alphabet, the ASL Alphabet. I taught myself out of the encyclopedia Britannic when I was five.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That was so sweet. Thank you so much, Cheryl.

All right, we want to get into the GDP when we come back.

And then there's this, a search for the sender intensifies, authorities now zeroing in on Florida after locating a tenth suspicious package sent to a prominent Democrat. RNC Chairwoman Ronna Romney McDaniel is here to weigh in. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Dualing rallies, President Trump is headed to North Carolina this evening, his predecessor, President Obama is in Wisconsin around the same time, this with what, 11 days to go before the midterm elections now. I want to bring in RNC chairman, Ronna Romney McDaniel. Ronna, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for joining us.

RONNA ROMNEY MCDANIEL, CHAIRWOMAN, RNC: Thanks for having me. Always good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, how are you feeling 11 days out? Tell us -- set the stage for us for these midterm elections. What's most important and what has changed?

MCDANIEL: Well, the most important thing obviously, is turning out your vote, making sure that your base has energy to go out and actually vote. And that's why the president is so instrumental as he's traveling from state to state and having these huge epic rallies like the one he had in Texas the other day, like the one he's going to have in North Carolina. He reminds voters not only go vote, talk to your family, sign up at Vote.GOP. We need to get these candidates over the finish line so I can keep this majority and keep this comeback going for the American people.

BARTIROMO: Now, the money has been an issue, right? The last time we spoke, we talked about a couple of very deep pocketed Democrats who were putting a lot of money into the Dimms and these Congressional races, like Michael Bloomberg giving $80 million to the Democrats. Tom Steyer in California $120 million. How are the Republicans doing on the money end of thing?

MCDANIEL: Yes, well, the progressive Democrat billionaires are trying to buy this election. And so, we know what this congressional members would do if they come to Washington. They'll be withhold unto the special interest. But the RNC has raised record money. We just passed $269 million raised. We're putting it into the ground game in all these states. We've been building it for two years.

So, we've made 60 million voter contacts, that's more than we did in 2016. And that's going to help really propel and drive out our vote as we're knocking doors, making calls, using digital and mail to talk to voters and we have something to say.

We've done things in Washington, four million new jobs, 4.2 percent GDP. Our country is on the rise. What are Democrats going to say? We've obstructed and resisted at every turn? They have nothing to run on except stopping this comeback that the American people are feeling in their pocketbooks.

BARTIROMO: And you've denounced this hate and these packages, the hunt is on this morning for whoever sent at least 10 suspicious packages to the presidents' most vocal critics.

The Feds turning their attention to Florida and New York this morning. Very early this morning President Trump tweeted this. Funny how lowly rated CNN and others can criticize me at will even blaming me for the current spate of bombs and ridiculously comparing this to September 11th and the Oklahoma City bombing. Yet, when I criticize them they go wild and scream it's just not presidential. Your reaction?

MCDANIEL: Well, I think the president has led the way on this when he has said this is a time to unify. He has condemned obviously these heinous acts by these cowardly individuals. And the Democrats did the exact opposite. They play the blame game. They continue to divide. You saw the head of CNN make a ridiculous statement, blaming this on the president and Sarah Sanders.

Once again, the Democrats cannot unify with this president and that is why we need more Republicans in Washington. We need to reject the Democrat playbook of resist, obstruct, divide, and the only way they rewrite the way they do business in Washington is if they lose and then we will get unity in Washington.

BARTIROMO: You know, there was Philippe Reines on Tucker the other night. He works -- obviously, he used to work with Hillary Clinton. And he basically said look, I'm very comfortable with Sarah Sanders getting kicked out of a restaurant, very comfortable with Kirstjen Nielsen getting kicked out of restaurants because they lie. So, I mean, it's almost like they continue to have this dog whistles.

MCDANIEL: Yes, it's shameful. It's not good for our country. And the president has stepped up and led.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Ronna, it's good to see you. Thanks very much.

MCDANIEL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Ronna Romney McDaniel.

Still ahead, markets are under pressure. We've got a lot more ahead of the GDP report out in 30 minutes, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
